page.title: 08SOCIAL LIFE IN THIS AREA
page.content: Fifty years ago villagers were able to support themselves and provide services for others within the commu- nity. Some who were not employed in local mines or on farms were skilled or semi-skilled craftsmen. Those who weren't sought seasonal work in the locality, proffered their services as odd-job men, or sold mushrooms, blackberries and crab apples picked from the fields and hedgerows. Some ladies washed and ironed clothes for others, or worked as servants in the homes of those who had regular work. Gipsy families would arrive each year to camp on the High Quarry. They would vie with Scottish pedlars to sell their cheap wares from door-to- door, whilst itinerant tramps would beg from house-holders known to be generous. Following the Second World War
